On July 7th, COVID-19 death toll reached 4 million worldwide. WHO Director-General said that in order to control the pandemic, designing a â€œglobal vaccination planâ€ is urgent. He also mentioned in the 138th meeting of the International Olympic Committee that the common goal must be to vaccinate 70% of the population of every country by the middle of next year to end the pandemic and reboot the global economy.

Last week, â€œreservation for vaccinationâ€ was the most popular topic among Facebook chinese posts and Taiwanese media reports. At the same time, as many as 13 suspicious narratives encouraging the public, explicitly or implicitly, â€œdonâ€™t to get vaccinatedâ€ appeared in the Taiwanese information sphere. Among them, 4 have been proven false. According to IORGâ€™s database, between July 12th and 18th, there are at least 4,50 LINE messages containing the word â€œvaccinesâ€. And there are at least 32 messages, which come from different 14 groups, spreading in total 13 suspicious narratives on â€œdonâ€™t get vaccinatedâ€. IORG put these suspicious narratives into 3 categories based on their â€œdegree of discouragementâ€: â€œWorse if vaccinatedâ€, â€œDonâ€™t get vaccinatedâ€, and â€œNo need to get vaccinatedâ€.

In addition, IORG found some of these narratives will combine together in a single message, possibly making the message more compelling. Compared to the conspiracy theory â€œvaccines are biochemical weaponsâ€ in volume 3, the 13 suspicious narratives observed in this volume offer more details, making them more convincing.  

These 13 suspicious narratives have 2 features. The first feature is that most of them â€œappeal to authorityâ€. Among them only 2 narratives cite unverified information as their source, and the other 11 all refer to the statements made by authorities such as doctors, immunologists, and medical personnels. Having the endorsement of â€œauthoritiesâ€ will make information receivers easier to believe in these narratives, despite the fact that the information itself might be manipulated. Another way to enhance the credibility of these narratives is to attach videos to the messages. 8 of these 13 suspicious narratives have videos attached to them, and 5 use the videos from a website called â€œRumbleâ€.

About â€œappeal to authorityâ€

â€œAppeal to authorityâ€ isnâ€™t necessarily a bad thing, unless the â€œauthorityâ€ that a message refers to is not a real or pertinent expert in the field, or the message twists the statement made by the authority. In that case, we can say the message â€œinappropriately appeal to authorityâ€, making it an information manipulation.

About â€œRumbleâ€

Rumble is a Canadian video sharing website created in 2013. According to Wikipedia, Rumble's monthly user count has experienced rapid growth since July 2020, from 1.6 million monthly users to 31.9 million by the end of the first quarter of 2021. Former US president Donald Trump officially joined Rumble on June 26, 2021.

The second feature of these narratives is that they often incite emotions like fear and distrust. Among them, 5 contain content that might provoke fear, saying that vaccines â€œwill cause cancerâ€, â€œmodify genesâ€, and â€œreduce lifespan.â€ Another 5 might induce readers' distrust towards the media and the government by saying that â€œthe media didnâ€™t report at allâ€, â€œthe government recommends vaccines that kill people.â€ There are also 4 narratives that claim they are providing â€œthe truthâ€, implying that readers have been fooled and making them question the societal consensus that â€œvaccination is beneficial in fighting the pandemic.â€
